Introduction

Amblyopia is a functional reduction in visual acuity that occurs due to abnormal development of the visual cortex in early childhood.  It is one of the most common causes of pediatric visual impairment.

Pathophysiology and risk factors



Normal development of the visual cortex requires appropriately focused visual stimulation from both eyes in early childhood.  Therefore, the development of amblyopia is a 2-step process, as follows:



  • Step 1:  Impaired transmission of a sharply focused image from both eyes due to an underlying ocular defect.
    • In deprivation amblyopia, this is due to obstruction of the visual axis (eg, cataract (
      figure 1
      ), ptosis, hemangioma).
    • In refractive amblyopia, this is due to an uncorrected asymmetric refractive error (eg, myopia, hyperopia (
      figure 2
      )).
    • In strabismic amblyopia, abnormal binocular interactions (eg, strabismus (
      figure 3
      )) lead to diplopia and suppression of the image from one eye.
  • Step 2:  Abnormal development of visual processing pathways due to impaired transmission of stimuli (
    figure 4
    ).


If the underlying ocular defect is not corrected in early childhood during the critical period of vision development (ie, by age 8-10), permanent cortical visual impairment can occur.  Patients with amblyopia have a functional reduction in visual acuity, which persists even if the ocular pathology is corrected later in life.  Amblyopia is usually unilateral but can be bilateral if there is abnormal visual stimulation from both eyes (eg, occlusion from bilateral cataracts).



The primary risk factor for amblyopia is having an underlying visual defect, which is more likely in certain conditions (eg, premature birth, eye injuries during childhood).

Clinical presentation



The clinical presentation of amblyopia varies depending on its underlying cause and severity.  Caregivers may notice subtle findings (eg, mild asymmetry between the patient's eyes, poor depth perception).  However, the majority of children with unilateral amblyopia are undiagnosed until routine vision screening is performed.

Diagnosis



Routine vision screening is the primary method of detecting amblyopia; screening is recommended in children ages 3-5 at their health maintenance visits.  Screening technique depends on the patient's age and development.  When amblyopia is suspected, a comprehensive eye examination should be performed, including assessment of:



  • Visual acuity:  This assesses the sharpness and clarity of vision (ie, ability of the eye to distinguish details) at a distance.  It is commonly evaluated with a standard vision chart (
    figure 5
    ).
  • Refraction:  Refraction refers to the focusing of an optical image on the retina.  A refraction test assesses for changes in visual acuity while the patient looks through various lenses in a phoropter (
    figure 6
    ).
  • Ocular alignment and motility:  To achieve normal binocular vision, the eyes must be properly aligned and have balanced/coordinated movement in all directions.  This can be assessed by examining extraocular movements evaluating the red reflex and corneal light reflection (
    figure 7
    ).
  • Stereopsis:  Because there is space between the eyes, images are perceived slightly differently in each eye.  This slight offset allows for depth perception.  Stereopsis tests measure a patient's ability to perceive depth by testing for the ability to detect targets that have contour.
  • Anterior and posterior segments of the eye:  This involves evaluating the structural components (eg, cornea, lens, retina) of the eye for abnormalities.  They are assessed with a slit-lamp examination and dilated funduscopic examination.


Based on this assessment, the diagnosis of amblyopia is made if one of the following criteria is met:



  • Difference in unilateral vision between eyes (best corrected visual acuity) â‰¥2 lines on a standard vision chart (eg, 20/20 in one eye and 20/30 in the other eye).
  • Best corrected visual acuity in both eyes is worse than 20/40 in children age â‰¥4.


Imaging studies (eg, optical coherence tomography) may be indicated if suspected structural abnormalities or optic nerve pathology interferes with visual acuity.  Laboratory evaluation is generally not required for the diagnosis of amblyopia.

Differential diagnosis



Although amblyopia occurs secondary to an underlying ocular defect (eg, refractive error, cataracts), not all patients with these defects develop amblyopia.  If visual acuity normalizes after correcting the primary ocular defect (eg, extracting the cataract), the patient does not have amblyopia.



If the patient has a functional reduction in visual acuity but no detectable ocular defect, primary disorders of the visual pathway (eg, structural brain lesions) should be considered.

Management



The management strategy of amblyopia involves first correcting the underlying ocular defect so that the image transmitted to the visual cortex from both eyes is sharp and focused.  These interventions include:



  • Removal of obstruction (eg, cataract) of the visual axis
  • Correction of refractive errors with glasses or contact lenses
  • Correction of ocular alignment in strabismus


After correcting the underlying defect, use of the amblyopic eye must be encouraged.  This can be done by occluding the better eye with either eye patching or pharmacologic blurring, forcing the visual cortex to recognize the signal coming from the amblyopic eye (

figure 3
).  As a result, the nerve pathways from the amblyopic eye are stimulated to develop.  Early intervention is crucial for promoting normal visual development.

Prognosis



The prognosis for amblyopia depends on various factors, including the age of onset, severity of visual impairment, compliance with treatment, and underlying ocular defect.  Early detection and intervention (ie, age <5) are crucial for optimizing visual outcomes (with many attaining visual acuity of 20/25 or better) and preventing permanent vision loss.  However, even if normal visual acuity is achieved, patients with a history of amblyopia may have deficits in other aspects of vision (eg, fine depth perception, hand-eye coordination).

Summary



Amblyopia is a disruption to the development of the visual cortex early in life, occurring as a secondary consequence of an underlying ocular pathology (eg, strabismus, cataracts) (
